Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Converting Greek yogurt waste into a low-calorie natural sweetener
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) program will be to develop a technology to convert the acid whey waste generated by Greek yogurt production into a natural sweetener. The Greek yogurt industry is on the rise. However, making authentic Greek yogurt is a wasteful process - producing 3 parts waste for every part of Greek yogurt made. An economical use of Greek yogurt waste will capture the full value of the waste materials, minimize waste transportation cost, decrease bacterial outbreak risk, and reduce the carbon footprint for the environment. In parallel, the technology will ensure a sustainable supply of a rare low-calorie natural sweetener, which was shown to help lower blood sugar and improve cholesterol levels, in addition to its antioxidant, anti-cavity and pro-digestive properties. The innovation will enhance scientific and technological understanding of conversion of non-food biomass to value-added chemicals.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to use synthetic biology and metabolic engineering to develop engineered yeast as a self-renewing biocatalyst for processing the environmentally hazardous waste from Greek yogurt production into a low-calorie natural sweetener. Greek yogurt companies struggle to dispose of its waste. The waste, which contains significant amounts of lactose, cannot be discarded without a pretreatment step because it stimulates bacterial growth, polluting water systems. The research addresses this challenge through the development of self-sustained microbes as catalysts in a continuous process, allowing lactose uptake with minimal waste pretreatment. This process produces a low-calorie natural sweetener as a product, whose market supply is currently limited by production cost. Anticipated technical results include strains with high yield and productivity, a specific product purification method and successful assembly of a live yeast reactor. The design overcomes substantial financial, logistical and thermodynamic bottlenecks in Greek yogurt waste treatment, and the low-calorie natural sweetener production.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fermentation can be used to produce a wide variety of molecules, from complex pharmaceuticals to fuels. This is possible due to advances in the strain engineering technology of microorganisms. So far, industrial scale fermentations have been successfully employed to manufacture high value molecules such as pharmaceuticals and fragrances. As more advances in strain engineering are being made, the scope for fermentation-based manufacturing is becoming wider to include molecules of lower values than the current products made via fermentation, such as food ingredients and commodity chemicals. Once the cost barrier is overcome, the advantages of using fermentation processes compared to conventional chemical processes can be tremendous, including sustainability and product specificity.

Zimitech is aiming to become one of the leaders of this movement, by introducing breakthrough biotechnology which will allow large scale manufacturing of food ingredients via fermentation. We have started with a plan to produce tagatose, an alternative sweetener with one third of the calories of sugar, via yeast fermentation using waste from Greek yogurt manufacturing. The goal was to repurpose what was previously considered as waste and to produce a healthy substitute for sugar in an economically viable way. However, while carrying out the tagatose portion of the project, discoveries were made which directly limited the economic viability of large scale tagatose project. This is due to the low price point of the alternative sweeteners.

Therefore, we pivoted to a product with a slightly higher price point to allow economic viability. This second product is 2’-fucosyllactose (2FL), which is a complex sugar existing naturally in human breast milk. Even though it does not have a sweet taste, it carries immense health benefits related to its prebiotic and antimicrobial properties. We have successfully demonstrated during this project that our approaches in genetically altering baker’s yeast allow us to increase the productivity of 2FL by 4-fold. We additionally were able to create a bench-top 2FL production process and to produce small amounts of purified 2FL. Our economic analysis performed for large-scale production of 2FL also confirms viability.

In conclusion, our project findings validate large-scale manufacturing of 2FL via fermentation, both technically and economically.
